ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the basics of photography as well as photoshop. We also learned how to print and present photos in a compelling way.
We learned how to use a camera, print, and take compelling photos. We learned about different ethical questions that come up in photography.

As my first photo class, I learned a lot about what makes a good photo in terms of composition, and expanded my vocabulary to talk about photos in a productive way when giving/receiving feedback. I learned a lot about lighting and overall how to work with the camera in terms of ISO and shutter speed.
How to take a photograph and the basics of what happens within the camera, how to use a DSL camera, and how a photographer sees.

Technical skills with a DSLR camera, including manually adjusting settings to achieve proper exposure, blur, etc. The artistic elements of a photograph. A general familiarity with the history of photography as a science and art. Exposure to the great artists of photography throughout its existence. Exposure to current photographers in the industry, along with their career and artistic advice.
digital photo and creating a final edit

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: Danna is an amazing professor that does a great job creating a supportive space. As a result the class felt very fun and comfortable. I couldnt have asked for a better environment to learn photography.
Weakness: It wouldve been nice to have more instruction on the technicals of photo making instead of crits and artist talks for the majority of classes. In this way the class is slightly less beginner friendly
Course is a wonderful entry level course and students learn a lot while also having independence. Danna is the biggest strength. no weaknesses

I feel like its strengths were in its people and supportive environment. I liked how we had different prompts for Crit, but how we could make Crit what we wanted it to be. I feel like it couldve been a bit more organized  as often times some people would get more time for crit than others or we would go on unproductive tangents.
Strength: Welcoming to new photographers, variety in experience of peers

Strengths: amazing and passionate professor and TF, as well as a supportive network of students and staff in general. Could be improved with more material resources from the university: there was a constant restriction in the tech I could rent due to low availability of cameras, lighting, and other equipment from CCAM. And I was surprised that printing paper wasn't abundantly provided by the university. Now that I'm thinking of that, I'm actually quite disappointed in the lack of material support from the administration, and the limits that places on what our professor and us students can do. Hm.
strengths only, the guest artists were incredible

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, this was a great course for someone like myself that had no background in photography. Danna and the rest of the class were amazing to learn from. I learned so much about photography, the study of art, and myself.
Absolutely, you learn so much and you can take these skills with you later in life.
Yes! I loved Danna and my TF Sophie. Although this was my first art course, they were never intimidating and were always super inviting and supportive of all questions no matter how basic.
Yes! What an amazing intro to photography. Its such a different environment than other classes at yale.

Yes, this is by far one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. It will completely change the way you think about and approach photography. I would recommend this class to anyone interested in photography; regardless of your level of experience, you will get so much out of it!
Absolutely- you learn a lot about photography both as a technical 'science' and skill, and as an art form. For many, it's a totally different classroom experience than they'd get anywhere else.
yes, the best part of the class was the guest artists.

Yes! I'm not sure if it'll be taught again and who will teach it in that case, but Danna was the absolute best! If Yale has the opportunity to welcome Danna back as a teacher again at some point, they should jump at the opportunity to do so (:
